facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 86 to 97 of 1962 filed with certificates granted by the High Court of Assam under Art. 132 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 86 to 97 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule Nos. 94-97, 105, 106, 114 and 175 to 179 of 1953. C. Setalvad, Sohan Shroff, P. K. Kapila and Sukumar Ghosh, for the appellants. Naunit Lal, for the respondents. February 4, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-These appeals have been filed with certificates granted by the High Court of Assam under Art. 132 of the Constitution against orders passed in certain petitions filed by the appellants praying for writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs quashing orders relating to assessment of sales-tax, and prohibiting the Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri and other officers from taking action in enforcement of the said orders.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule Nos. 94-97, 105, 106, 114 and 175 to 179 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule Nos. 94-97, 105, 106, 114 and 175 to 179 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 4, 1964 by SHAH J.

anchor.surface_text: February 4, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-These appeals have been filed with certificates granted by the High Court of Assam under Art. 132 of the Constitution against orders passed in certain petitions filed by the appellants praying for writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs quashing orders relating to assessment of sales-tax, and prohibiting the Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri and other officers from taking action in enforcement of the said orders. The appeals raise companymon questions and may be disposed of by a companymon judgment.

facts.text: Appellants are merchants carrying on business as dealers in jute, principal place of business at Calcutta, branch office at Dhubri in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are merchants carrying on business as dealers in jute, and have their principal place of business at Calcutta. The appellants have a branch office at Dhubri in the State of Assam and are registered dealers under the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947  17 of 1947 . The appellants purchased jute at Dhubri and other places in the State of Assam and despatched bales of jute to diverse factories ,outside the Province of Assam.

facts.text: Appellants are registered dealers under the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have a branch office at Dhubri in the State of Assam and are registered dealers under the Assam Sales Tax Act, 1947  17 of 1947 .

facts.text: Appellants purchased jute at Dhubri and other places in Assam and despatched bales to factories outside Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants purchased jute at Dhubri and other places in the State of Assam and despatched bales of jute to diverse factories ,outside the Province of Assam.

facts.text: Appellants submitted returns of turnover for sales-tax for period March 1948 to March 1950 to Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted returns of turnover for purposes of sales-tax before the Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, under the Assam Sales Tax Act in respect of transactions of sale during the period between March 1948 to March 1950.

facts.text: Superintendent of Taxes called upon appellants under s.17(2) to produce books and evidence, granted time, but appellants failed to comply.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of Taxes called upon the appellants under s. 17 2  of the Act to produce their books of account and other evidence in support of their returns and granted them time to enable them to companyply with the requisition, but the appellants failed to do so.

facts.text: Superintendent of Taxes made best judgment assessments under s.17(4) and issued demand notices.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of Taxes then made best judgment assessments exercising his powers under s. 17 4  of the Act and issued demand numberices for the tax determined.

facts.text: Appellants preferred appeals to Assistant Commissioner of Taxes, produced some but not all books.

anchor.surface_text: Against the orders passed by the Superintendent of Taxes appeals were preferred to the Assistant Com- missioner of Taxes. Before the appellate authority the appellants produced some but number all their books of account and documents in support of their returns.

facts.text: Before Assistant Commissioner, appellants contended that definition of sale in s.2(12) ultra vires, tax on sales outside state, export tax, and goods not bales in Assam per Explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Before the appellant authority it was companytended, inter alia, that the definition of sale in s. 2 12  of the Act was beyond the legislative companypetence of the Provincial Legislature, that tax was sought to be levied on sales effected outside the State, and that imposition of sales tax on the transactions of the appellant amounted to levying an export tax which was number open to the Provincial Legislature. It was however number companytended before the Assistant Commissioner of Taxes that the jute bales, sale price of which was included in the turnover were number at the time of the companytracts in the form of jute bales actually within the State of Assam and there- fore the Explanation to s. 2 12  did number make that sale price liable to be included in the turnover of the appellants.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner of Taxes dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Commissioner of Taxes, Assam, dismissed the appeals.

facts.text: In revision to Commissioner, appellants contended for first time that goods not in Province at time of contracts per Explanation to s.2(12).

anchor.surface_text: In the revision applications preferred to the Commissioner of Taxes, Assam, against the order of the Assistant Com- missioner of Taxes it was companytended for the first time that the price of jute included in the turnover under the orders passed by the Superintendent of Taxes was number liable to be taxed because within the meaning of the Explanation to s. 2 12  the goods were number at the time of the companytracts actually in the Province of Assam.

facts.text: Commissioner rejected contention after examining time-table of jute cultivation: planted about February, ready June, marketing July to June next; contracts March-September, deliveries after July, so last year's crop in Province.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner rejected the companytention after examining what he called the time-table of cultivation. He observed that the usual time for marketing jute of the new crop was between July and June of the following year, jute being planted in or 134-159 S.C.-42. about February and being ready for marketing some time about the month of June. The Commissioner further observed that the companytracts were made on diverse dates between March and September and deliveries under the companytracts were made after the month of July when the new crop was brought into the market. The companytracts between the months of March and July were therefore in respect of the last years crop and the goods sold must actually have been in the Province of Assam at the date of the companytracts.

facts.text: Commissioner made certain modifications in assessment but not concerned in appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner made certain modifications in the assessment order, but with those modifications we are number companycerned in these appeals.

facts.text: Appellants filed petitions under Art. 226 for certiorari and prohibition against Commissioner's order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Commissioner, petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution were filed by the appellants for writs of certiorari and prohibition.

facts.text: High Court held Explanation to s.2(12) ultra vires pre-Constitution, no evidence from books that goods not in Assam, Commissioner's reasons unjustified, declined to consider factual findings, granted cert under Art.132.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the Explanation to s. 2 12  was. in respect of the period prior to the Constitution, number ultra vires the authority of the Provincial Legislature, and that numberattempt was made to establish before the appellate authority that the books of account supported the companytention that the goods were number actually in existence in the State of Assam at the time of the companytracts of sale. Holding that the reasons which the Commissioner had given in support of his finding were number altogether unjustified and that the taxing authorities being fully companyscious that one of the essential ingredients of tax liability was that the goods must be actually in existence in the State of Assam at the time of the companytracts of sale, the High Court declined to companysider whether the companyclusions of the taxing authorities on questions of fact were companyrect. But the High Court held that the plea about the vires of s. 2 12  and the Explanation thereto raised a substantial question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, and accordingly granted certificates of fitness under Art. 132 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court refused leave to challenge factual finding that goods were in Assam at contract time.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of these appeals companynsel for the appellants sought leave to challenge the companyrectness of the decision that the goods were when the companytracts were made actually within the Province of Assam. We have heard companynsel for the appellants at great length upon this application for leave to appeal on grounds other than companystitutional on which the certificates were granted by the High Court. After carefully companysidering the arguments, we are of the view that numbercase has been made out for acceding to that request.

facts.text: Appellants failed to produce all books before Superintendent and Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are dealers registered under the Assam Sales Tax Act submitted their returns to the Superintendent of Taxes, but failed when called upon to produce their books of account and other evidence in support of their returns. Even before the Assistant Commissioner, they produced some but number all their books of account and evidence demanded by the Superintendent.

facts.text: Contracts made on diverse dates between March and September.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner further observed that the companytracts were made on diverse dates between March and September and deliveries under the companytracts were made after the month of July when the new crop was brought into the market.

facts.text: All appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: All the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

The appeals raise common questions and may be disposed of by a common judgment.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals have been filed with certificates granted by the High Court of Assam under Art. 132 of the Constitution against orders passed in certain petitions filed by the appellants praying for writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs quashing orders relating to assessment of sales-tax,

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Commissioner, petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution were filed by the appellants for writs of certiorari and prohibition.

concepts.unlisted_description: Writ to prohibit inferior tribunal from exceeding jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution is clothed in wide terms and the exercise thereof is not subject to any restrictions except the territorial restrictions which are expressly provided in the Article. But the exercise of the jurisdiction is discretionary it is not exercised merely because it is lawful to do so. The very amplitude of the jurisdiction demands that it will ordinarily be exercised subject to certain self-imposed limitations. Resort to that jurisdiction is not intended as an alternative remedy for relief which may be obtained in a suit or other mode prescribed by statute.

concepts.interpretation: Writ jurisdiction under Art.226 not exercised where efficacious alternative statutory remedy available; party must exhaust statutory machinery before invoking writ

anchor.surface_text: The scheme evolved by the Legislature for determination of tax liability is that all questions of fact are to be decided by the taxing authorities and on questions of law arising out of the decision of the taxing authorities the opinion of High Court may be obtained. The High Court has however no power to decide questions of fact, which are exclusively within the competence of the taxing authorities.

concepts.interpretation: Whether finding unsupported by evidence or perverse is question of law referable to HC; facts exclusively for taxing authorities

holdings.text: No case has been made out for granting leave to challenge the correctness of the factual finding that goods were in Assam at time of contracts, as it is not a certified ground under Art. 132.

anchor.surface_text: After carefully considering the arguments, we are of the view that no case has been made out for acceding to that request. A person appealing to this Court under Art. 132 of the Constitution may not challenge the correctness or propriety of the decision appealed against on grounds other than those on which the certificate is granted, unless this Court grants him leave to raise other questions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arguments considered at length; no grave miscarriage of justice or substantial non-constitutional questions warranting Art. 136 leave.

holdings.text: A person appealing under Art. 132 may not challenge grounds other than those certified unless Supreme Court grants leave.

anchor.surface_text: A person appealing to this Court under Art. 132 of the Constitution may not challenge the correctness or propriety of the decision appealed against on grounds other than those on which the certificate is granted, unless this Court grants him leave to raise other questions. Such leave is generally granted where the trial before the High Court has resulted in grave miscarriage of justice or where the appeal raises such substantial questions that on an application made to this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution leave would be granted to the applicant to appeal against the decision on those questions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle limiting appeals to certified constitutional questions unless exceptional circumstances.

holdings.text: Leave under Art. 132 for non-certified grounds granted only for grave miscarriage of justice or substantial questions meriting Art. 136 leave.

anchor.surface_text: Such leave is generally granted where the trial before the High Court has resulted in grave miscarriage of justice or where the appeal raises such substantial questions that on an application made to this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution leave would be granted to the applicant to appeal against the decision on those questions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established practice for granting leave in constitutional appeals.

holdings.text: High Court under Art. 226 will not exercise jurisdiction to bypass statutory remedies or decide factual questions reserved for taxing authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution is clothed in wide terms and the exercise thereof is not subject to any restrictions except the territorial restrictions which are expressly provided in the Article. But the exercise of the jurisdiction is discretionary it is not exercised merely because it is lawful to do so. The very amplitude of the jurisdiction demands that it will ordinarily be exercised subject to certain self-imposed limitations. Resort to that jurisdiction is not intended as an alternative remedy for relief which may be obtained in a suit or other mode prescribed by statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary jurisdiction not to be used as alternative to efficacious statutory appeals, revisions, and references under ss. 30,31,32; facts exclusively for taxing authorities.

holdings.text: High Court has no power to decide questions of fact exclusively within competence of taxing authorities; only questions of law via s.32 reference.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme evolved by the Legislature for determination of tax liability is that all questions of fact are to be decided by the taxing authorities and on questions of law arising out of the decision of the taxing authorities the opinion of High Court may be obtained. The High Court has however no power to decide questions of fact, which are exclusively within the competence of the taxing authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory hierarchy: facts by taxing officers, law by HC on reference; perverse findings as question of law.

holdings.text: Whether Commissioner's decision unsupported by evidence or perverse is question of law arising out of order, referable under s.32.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has however no power to decide questions of fact, which are exclusively within the competence of the taxing authorities. The High Court is again not an appellate authority over the decision of the Commissioner it has merely to give its opinion on questions of law arising out of the order of the Commissioner. Whether the decision of the Commissioner is not supported by any evidence, or is based upon a view of facts which could never be reasonably entertained, is a question of law which arises out of the order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between fact and law in tax proceedings.

holdings.text: Explanation to s.2(12) not ultra vires GOI Act 1935; provincial legislature competent to deem sales in province if goods there at contract time.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature has thereby not overstepped the limits of its authority The Tata Iron Steel Company Ltd. v. The State of Bihar 1 . No argument has therefore been advanced before us to support the plea of unconstitutionality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Tata Iron & Steel; fiction for tax situs valid exercise of power to tax sales of goods.

holdings.text: Taxpayer must place all material before taxing authorities; cannot bypass via writ after failing to produce evidence or exhaust remedies.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are dealers registered under the Assam Sales Tax Act submitted their returns to the Superintendent of Taxes, but failed when called upon to produce their books of account and other evidence in support of their returns. Even before the Assistant Commissioner, they produced some but not all their books of account and evidence demanded by the Superintendent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature contemplates full evidence before taxing authorities for fair adjudication; writ not for appellate review.
